study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on cognitive performance and identify moderating factors such as intervention cycle and age.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved information processing, executive function, and memory, with benefits varying by age group and intervention duration. Acute HIIT enhanced executive function, while chronic HIIT (over 8 weeks) improved all three cognitive domains.
population_specificity: Individuals across various age groups, including those aged 30-60 and 60+.
study_duration: Varied (acute, less than 8 weeks, and more than 8 weeks)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a school-based HIIT program on quality of life and physical fitness in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT significantly improved physical well-being and fitness metrics, including countermovement jump, agility, medicine ball throw, and sit-ups, compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 60 male adolescents (16.2 ± 0.6 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of long-term low-volume HIIT on emotional conflict control and prefrontal cortex activation in males with methamphetamine use disorder (MUD).
results_summary: The 36-week HIIT intervention reduced emotional conflict, increased activation in the right dorsolateral and ventrolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC and vlPFC), and decreased subjective craving in males with MUD, while the control group showed no significant changes.
population_specificity: Forty males with methamphetamine use disorder (MUD), aged 31.50 ± 4.33 years.
effective_dosage: Low-volume HIIT (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of HIIT on plasma volume variations in obese women, focusing on how menopausal status and age influence these changes.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT led to significant reductions in anthropometric measures and blood pressure, with notable decreases in plasma volume. Age and menopausal status were significant predictors of plasma volume changes, with menopause accounting for 19-21% of the variation post-HIIT.
population_specificity: Fifty-nine obese perimenopausal and postmenopausal women, average age 56.6 years.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of high-intensity interval training on lipid metabolism and inflammatory factors in overweight children and provide clinical guidance for weight management.
results_summary: High-intensity interval training significantly reduced BMI, improved lipid metabolism (triglycerides, total cholesterol, lipoprotein levels), and lowered inflammatory markers (tumor necrosis factor alpha, C-reactive protein) in overweight children compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Overweight children (60 participants, male and female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and benefits of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in improving cardiovascular and metabolic health, particularly in patients recovering from heart attacks and strokes.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved cardiovascular fitness (VO2 max, endothelial function, cardiac output) and metabolic health (glycemic control, lipid profile). It also enhanced functional recovery and quality of life in stroke patients, with evidence suggesting it is safe and well-tolerated under proper supervision.
population_specificity: General population and patients with chronic cardiovascular diseases, particularly those recovering from heart attacks and strokes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on highly trained athletes, focusing on performance measures beyond maximum oxygen uptake and the moderating effects of different HIIT types.
results_summary: HIIT showed substantial improvements in various performance measures for some athlete subgroups, with aerobic HIIT types enhancing V˙O2max (+2.6%) and longer-duration tests benefiting sprint (+5.5%) and time trial (+4.9%) performance. However, effects varied by setting, and uncertainty remained regarding exercise economy and moderators like sex and HIIT type.
population_specificity: Highly trained endurance and elite athletes.
effective_dosage: Not specified (6 types of HIIT analyzed).
study_duration: Up to 6 weeks (specific durations varied by study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of HIIT and MICT on enjoyment and affective responses in overweight or obese individuals to determine the most suitable exercise mode.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT produced similar enjoyable and positive affective responses in overweight and obese individuals, with HIIT leading to higher enjoyment and similar affective responses compared to MICT.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese individuals aged 18-70 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (various forms of HIIT and MICT interventions were used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Sprint Interval Training (SIT) on multiple cardiometabolic health markers in children and adolescents.
results_summary: HIIT improved insulin, insulin resistance, lipid profile (TG, TC, LDL, HDL), and systolic blood pressure (SBP), but did not affect glucose or diastolic blood pressure (DBP). SIT showed particularly strong benefits in those with obesity.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 6-18 years, including those with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of HIIT interventions on exercise capacity and fatigue in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that HIIT significantly improved exercise capacity (SMD = 0.29, p = 0.02) and reduced fatigue (SMD = -0.26, p = 0.03) in people with MS, with low risk of bias and good methodological quality.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on health-related fitness components in adolescents.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness (SRT and VO2max) and strength measures (hand grip, SLJ, CMJ) in adolescents compared to the control group, with statistically significant and clinically meaningful improvements.
population_specificity: 60 adolescents (age 16.33 ± 0.62 years) from a secondary Grammar school.
effective_dosage: Two Tabata sessions per week, each lasting 4 minutes, during physical education classes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether concurrent HIIT and resistance training could similarly enhance cardiorespiratory fitness and metabolic health markers in patients with type-1 or type-2 diabetes compared to healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found that combined HIIT and resistance training improved cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2peak, ventilatory threshold, workload) in both T1D and T2D patients, with T1D patients showing similar improvements to healthy controls, while T2D patients exhibited additional benefits in insulin sensitivity, body composition, and visceral adipose tissue reduction, though their VO2peak improvements were lower than healthy controls.
population_specificity: Adults with uncomplicated type-1 or type-2 diabetes and healthy normoglycemic controls matched for sex and age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of HIIT combined with resistance training versus HIIT alone on body composition, cardiorespiratory fitness, and glycolipid metabolism in young women with overweight/obesity.
results_summary: Both HIIT+RT and HIIT alone significantly improved body composition, cardiorespiratory fitness, and glycolipid metabolism, but the combined training showed greater improvements in muscle mass, VO2peak, VC, and VO2/HR.
population_specificity: Young women with overweight/obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the characteristics, prescription methods, and safety of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) protocols used in cancer patients to determine their effectiveness and replicability.
results_summary: Only 50% of studies provided all necessary variables for accurate HIIT prescription, with most using the HIIT-long format. Few studies employed individualized anchors (e.g., anaerobic threshold), and adverse events were rarely reported (34 studies reported none, 10 did not mention them).
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing treatment or post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) with probiotics supplementation produces additive effects on anthropometric and cardiorespiratory outcomes in obese middle-aged women.
results_summary: HIIT improved time to exhaustion (TTE) but increased waist circumference compared to controls. Combining HIIT with probiotics counteracted the negative waist circumference effect, enhanced TTE, and significantly reduced hip circumference, showing a synergistic effect.
population_specificity: Obese middle-aged women (age 44.5 ± 5.94 years, body fat percentage 40.0 ± 4.1%).
effective_dosage: HIIT: 85-90% vVO2max for 2 min, followed by 1-min rest, repeated for 7 cycles, 3 sessions/week. Probiotics: Lactiplantibacillus plantarum TWK10, 6 × 10^10 CFU/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) induces an epigenetic memory in human skeletal muscle, characterized by retained DNA methylation and gene expression changes after detraining and retraining.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT led to improved V̇o2max and induced hypomethylation at specific genomic regions, which persisted during detraining and retraining. Five genes related to lactate transport and calcium signaling showed retained hypomethylation and increased expression, indicating an epigenetic memory of HIIT despite similar physiological adaptations between training phases.
population_specificity: Twenty healthy subjects (25 ± 5 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT interventions lasted 2 months each).
study_duration: Two 2-month HIIT interventions separated by 3 months of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of resistance training (RT) and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on body composition, physical fitness, and quality of life in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and reduced fat mass, while both HIIT and RT improved lean mass, muscle strength, and quality of life domains. No major adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (Stage I-III), post-treatment, aged 55.5 ± 8.8 years, with a BMI of 27.9 ± 5 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of high-intensity aerobic interval training (HIIT) on quality of life and neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) side effects in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: HIIT reduced breast cancer symptom scale outcomes, alleviated systemic therapy side effects, and lowered cancer-related symptoms. However, psychological side effects were more common in the HIIT group compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Women (ages 35-64) diagnosed with locally advanced (stage II-III) ER+ breast cancer receiving doxorubicin/cyclophosphamide-based NAC.
effective_dosage: 2 to 3 HIIT sessions per week (4 × 4 minutes at 85%-95% peak heart rate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effectiveness of HIIT on oxygen consumption performance (VO2max, YYIRT, RSA) in male team-sport athletes.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved VO2max, YYIRT, and RSA performance but showed no significant effects on VIFT and MAS. The meta-analysis supported these findings with statistically significant effect sizes.
population_specificity: Male team-sport athletes aged 14-26 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the isolated and synergistic effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and a very low carbohydrate high fat (VLCHF) diet on mental health-related indicators in individuals with excessive weight or obesity.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in mental health-related indicators between groups after 12 weeks, except for a medium improvement in life satisfaction (SWLS) in the VLCHF + HIIT group compared to the HIIT group alone. HIIT and VLCHF, alone or combined, did not significantly affect mental health-related indicators.
population_specificity: Individuals with excessive weight or obesity (age 20-60 years, BMI 29.8 ± 3.7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-week school-based HIIT intervention on various health and fitness outcomes among 12-13-year-olds.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a planned evaluation of HIIT's impact on cardiorespiratory fitness, physical activity, body composition, muscular strength, bone health, cognitive function, wellbeing, and academic performance, but results are not yet reported.
population_specificity: 12-13-year-old students from a secondary school in Ningbo, China.
effective_dosage: 6 to 10-minute HIIT sessions embedded in physical education or activity lessons five days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of an 8-week supervised HIIT program versus self-performed moderate-to-vigorous physical activity in preventing blood pressure disorders and improving cardiorespiratory fitness in pregnant women.
results_summary: Both HIIT and self-performed moderate-to-vigorous physical activity maintained normal blood pressure in pregnant women, with HIIT additionally improving cardiorespiratory fitness (VO2peak and HRmax). No significant differences in post-CPET blood pressure changes were observed between groups post-intervention.
population_specificity: 54 Caucasian women with uncomplicated, singleton pregnancies (age 32 ± 4 years, 22 ± 4 weeks of gestation).
effective_dosage: Three HIIT sessions per week supplemented by one weekly educational class.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and low-intensity training (LIT) on serum BDNF levels in individuals with PTSD.
results_summary: HIIT transiently increased serum BDNF levels post-exercise on both measured days, but neither HIIT nor LIT led to sustained increases over the 12-day training period. The effects were controlled for platelet counts.
population_specificity: 40 participants (80% female) diagnosed with PTSD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) could restore mitophagy levels suppressed by breast cancer and reduce tumor burden in mice.
results_summary: HIIT restored mitophagy-related protein expression levels in breast tissue and significantly reduced tumor volume relative to body weight in mice with breast cancer compared to the non-exercising cancer group.
population_specificity: Female BALB/c mice with induced mammary tumors.
effective_dosage: 4-10 intervals of running at 80-100% of maximum speed, 40 sessions over 8 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on vascular dysfunction in hypertensive rats and explore underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT protected against hypertension equally, but MICT was better for weight control and vascular morphology preservation, while HIIT was more effective in reducing oxidative stress. Both exercise types improved vascular dysfunction by suppressing NLRP3-induced pyroptosis, with HIIT's benefits linked to AMPKα-SIRT1 activation.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHR) and Wistar Kyoto rats (WKY) as controls.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treadmill training protocol details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of combining Hibiscus sabdariffa (Hs) and High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on metabolic adaptations and lipid metabolism in obese rats.
results_summary: HIIT reduced caloric intake, body adiposity, and body weight gain while improving physical performance and glycemic profile. The combination of Hs and HIIT enhanced these effects, particularly in reducing food consumption and improving hepatoprotection, but did not alter lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: Obese Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 150 mg/kg of body weight (Hs extract, daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and effects of a HIIT app as a remote exercise support strategy for children with obesity, focusing on adherence, obesity-related outcomes, and user perceptions.
results_summary: The study found modest adherence (2.5 sessions/week) and no significant changes in body composition, physical activity, or most nutritional behaviors, except for a slight reduction in sugary beverage intake. Most children perceived improvements in nutritional behavior and wellbeing, though no objective benefits were observed.
population_specificity: Children with obesity (mean age 10.4 years, 94.6% with obesity, 45.9% girls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a 12-week HIIT program to a 12-month multidisciplinary lifestyle intervention would improve BMI z-score, waist circumference, blood pressure, and health-related quality of life in children and adolescents with obesity.
results_summary: Adding HIIT did not significantly improve BMI z-score compared to the lifestyle intervention alone but improved health-related quality of life at 3 months, though this benefit diminished by 12 months. No significant differences were found for waist circumference or blood pressure.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity (N=173).
effective_dosage: Three weekly HIIT sessions for 12 weeks, with activities eliciting intensities >85% of maximal heart rate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of two volumes of high-intensity interval training (low vs. high) on vascular-endothelial function in individuals after an acute myocardial infarction.
results_summary: Both low-volume and high-volume HIIT improved endothelial function (↑FMD), reduced atherosclerosis markers (↓cIMT), and lowered oxidative stress (↓ox-LDL), with greater benefits observed in the high-volume group. No significant changes occurred in the control group.
population_specificity: 80 post-acute myocardial infarction patients (58.4 ± 8.3 years, 82.5% men).
effective_dosage: Low-volume HIIT (<10 min high intensity per session) and high-volume HIIT (>10 min high intensity per session), twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine how different HIIT protocol characteristics (interval duration, training volume, intervention period) influence anthropometrics, glycemic control, and cardiorespiratory fitness in T2DM patients compared to control and MICT.
results_summary: Long-duration, high-volume, and long-term HIIT showed superior outcomes for body mass, waist circumference, glycemic control, and CRF compared to control conditions. HIIT outperformed MICT in body mass and CRF improvements under specific protocol conditions, but no differences were found in glycemic control between HIIT and MICT.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied by HIIT protocol characteristics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) could improve physical fitness and reduce binge eating disorder (BED) symptoms in young inactive females with mild to moderate BED.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved body weight, fat mass, and BMI but did not show significant improvements in BED symptoms. HIIT and Yoga both significantly increased VO2max compared to the control group, with no difference between the two interventions.
population_specificity: 47 young inactive females with mild to moderate binge eating disorder (BED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 4-week intervention combining small-sided games (SSGs) and high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on physical fitness in collegiate male soccer players.
results_summary: The intervention group showed small to moderate improvements in repeated sprint ability (4.5%), countermovement jump (3.2%), and intermittent fitness (6.8%), but these changes were not statistically significant. The study concluded that the combined SSGs and HIIT approach had limited impact on physical fitness over the 4-week period.
population_specificity: Collegiate male soccer players (n=21)
effective_dosage: Eight sessions over 4 weeks (four SSGs and four HIIT)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine barriers and enablers of adherence to High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in patients diagnosed with cancer.
results_summary: Weighted adherence to HIIT was 88%, with no serious adverse events reported. Adherence was higher when interventions were supervised, shorter in duration, and conducted during pre- or post-treatment phases.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with any type of cancer, across various stages of treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two game-based physical activity interventions (GameHIIT and GameSAE) on executive function and health indicators in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in executive function or ADHD symptoms in either intervention group, but both game-based programs significantly enhanced physical activity levels and physical fitness compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Children with ADHD

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the hepatoprotective effects of preconditioning with high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus traditional continuous training of low and moderate intensities on inflammatory markers in female rats with cisplatin-induced hepatotoxicity.
results_summary: HIIT was the only protocol to prevent increases in pro-inflammatory cytokines, reduce ED-1-positive cells, attenuate the TLR4/NF-κB pathway, increase anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10, and regulate M1/M2 macrophage polarization, suggesting superior hepatoprotective effects compared to low and moderate-intensity training.
population_specificity: Female Wistar rats with cisplatin-induced hepatotoxicity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (treadmill running protocols for 8 weeks).
study_duration: 8 weeks of training before cisplatin treatment, with euthanasia 7 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) with other exercise types (aerobic, resistance, and endurance training) in improving outcomes like exercise capacity, pulmonary function, and quality of life in stable COPD patients.
results_summary: HIIT was found to be the most favorable exercise type for enhancing 6-minute walk test distance (6MWD), with an 82.9% probability of being the most effective. However, it was not the top performer in improving pulmonary function or quality of life, where endurance training and resistance training showed superiority, respectively.
population_specificity: 951 patients with stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on blood lactate clearance in adult males.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT significantly improved blood lactate clearance after 8 weeks, with HIIT showing superior effectiveness at 15 and 30 minutes post-test compared to MICT.
population_specificity: 21 adult males

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of supramaximal HIIT compared to MICT on extrapulmonary manifestations (cognitive function, cardiorespiratory fitness, muscle power) in people with COPD and healthy controls, as well as its impact on neurodegeneration trajectories.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, but it hypothesizes that supramaximal HIIT may provide a more optimal stimulus for training adaptations while reducing ventilatory burden compared to MICT in COPD patients. It also seeks to explore HIIT's potential to mitigate neurodegeneration and systemic inflammation.
population_specificity: People with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) (n=92) and matched healthy controls (n=70).
effective_dosage: Watt-based cycling 2-3 times weekly (specific intensity details not provided).
study_duration: 12 weeks for phase 1, 24 months for phase 2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of HIIT versus MICT in alleviating sarcopenia and to explore the role of EEF1E1 in muscle aging and atrophy.
results_summary: HIIT was more effective than MICT in reducing EEF1E1 expression, mitigating age-related muscle decline, and improving muscle differentiation in aged mice. EEF1E1 was associated with sarcopenia markers in elderly humans, and its downregulation counteracted myoblast senescence.
population_specificity: Sedentary adults (human trial), elderly individuals (case-control study), and young/aged mice (preclinical study).
effective_dosage: HIIT (four 4-min intervals at 70% maximal capacity alternating with 4 min at 30%), MICT (constant 50% maximal capacity), five sessions/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous aerobic training on physical fitness, biochemical parameters, and liver function in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: HIIT showed superior improvements in cardiorespiratory fitness, muscular strength, and metabolic, inflammatory, and oxidative stress profiles compared to aerobic training, with significant reductions in triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, liver enzymes, inflammatory markers, insulin resistance, and oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Sixty NAFLD patients (32 males, 28 females; age: 49.7±8.7 years; BMI: 31.1±3.3 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: HIIT consisted of 4-minute high-intensity intervals at 85-95% of peak heart rate, interspersed with 3-minute active recovery at 60-70% of peak heart rate, for 30-40 minutes per session, thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on physical fitness and health parameters in older adults compared to non-exercise and other-exercise conditions.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved resting heart rate, systolic blood pressure, cardiorespiratory fitness, body fat percentage, muscular strength, muscular endurance, and balance in older adults compared to non-exercise conditions, and outperformed other-exercise conditions in improving resting heart rate, systolic blood pressure, and cardiorespiratory fitness. No significant differences were found for diastolic blood pressure, BMI, or waist circumference.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥60 years (mean age 60.5-81.2 years, 52.1% female).
study_duration: Minimum 2-week intervention (exact duration varied across included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the long-term effects of a 12-week HIIT intervention on left ventricular mass, pulmonary diffusing capacity, symptom severity, and functional capacity in patients previously hospitalized for COVID-19.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT preserved left ventricular mass at 12-month follow-up but did not significantly affect pulmonary diffusing capacity or symptom severity compared to standard care. Both groups showed similar improvements in symptom severity and functional status.
population_specificity: Patients recently discharged from hospital due to COVID-19.
effective_dosage: 4 × 4 min sessions, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of HIIT compared to MICT and non-exercise control for improving metabolic syndrome components and cardiometabolic health outcomes in individuals with MetS.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved waist circumference, blood pressure, HDL-C, triglycerides, and fasting blood glucose compared to control, with effects comparable to MICT. Low-volume HIIT was not inferior to higher-volume protocols for improving MetS components.
population_specificity: Individuals with metabolic syndrome (mean age 46.2-67.0 years, 55% male).
effective_dosage: Low-volume HIIT (<15 min of high-intensity exercise per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of HIIT on cardiomyocyte contractile function and intracellular Ca2+ handling in obese rats.
results_summary: HIIT reduced visceral fat, increased maximum oxygen consumption, improved gastrocnemius fiber diameter, decreased collagen fraction, enhanced cardiomyocyte contractility, and improved myofilament sensitivity to Ca2+ in obese rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with obesity induced by a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an 8-week HIIT program versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on body composition and cardiovascular metabolic outcomes in sedentary adolescents.
results_summary: Both HIIT and MICT similarly reduced body fat mass, fat percentage, and visceral fat area, but HIIT showed additional benefits in improving waist/hip ratio and cardiometabolic health markers like blood pressure and triglycerides. No significant differences were found in clinical biomarkers between groups, and insulin resistance improvements were limited.
population_specificity: Sedentary, normal-weight adolescents in China (18.5 ± 0.3 years, 11 females).
effective_dosage: HIIT protocol: three sessions/week of "all out" sprints to reach 85%-95% of HRmax.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of high-intensity interval training (HIIT), alone or combined with caloric restriction (CR), on metabolic dysfunction and peripheral neuropathy (PN) in high-fat diet (HFD) mice.
results_summary: HIIT alone did not improve metabolic dysfunction but improved PN similarly to CR and HIIT-CR. HIIT-CR activated AMPK, a fuel-sensing enzyme, suggesting a potential neuroprotective mechanism.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-induced obese mice with peripheral neuropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and strength exercise on cardiovascular health, physical fitness, and overall health in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: The study found that supervised HIIT and strength exercise significantly improved cardiovascular health (VO2max), physical fitness (O2-pulse, sit-to-stand, handgrip strength), and overall health without worsening pain or disease activity in RA patients. No significant improvements were observed for pain, disease activity (DAS28), or erythrocyte sedimentation rate.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (86% female, aged 20-60 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT and strength exercise for 12 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of Low-Volume High-Intensity Interval Training (LV-HIIT) on fatty liver index (FLI) and estimated Glomerular Filtration Rate (eGFR) in patients with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: LV-HIIT significantly reduced FLI and increased eGFR in T2DM patients, while also improving Fasting Blood Sugar (FBS), Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT), and Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT) levels compared to the control group. The control group only showed a significant reduction in FBS.
population_specificity: 80 sedentary patients with T2DM (HbA1C 6.4%-10%) and a history of diabetes for at least one year.
effective_dosage: 3 sessions per week (specific intensity/duration not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on blood pressure, body composition, and blood biomarkers in coronary artery disease (CAD) patients.
results_summary: HIIT showed superior improvements in body fat mass, waist circumference, hemoglobin A1c, and thyrotropin compared to MICT, with both exercise programs outperforming the control group in all measured variables.
population_specificity: 72 CAD patients (14% women).
effective_dosage: HIIT targeted ≈ 85-95% of peak heart rate, conducted thrice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on cognitive and physical skills in basketball and soccer players.
results_summary: The HIIT intervention significantly improved cognitive performance (e.g., 15% better motion object tracking, 16% increased working memory) and physical skills (e.g., 6% faster sprint times, 8% improved change-of-direction). Both groups showed notable post-intervention improvements.
population_specificity: 10 soccer players and 10 basketball players, average age 22.79 ± 1.90 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (HIIT protocol based on Wingate technique).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-intensity interval training improves sleep quality in individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder compared to low-to-moderate-intensity training.
results_summary: Both high-intensity interval training and low-to-moderate-intensity training improved sleep quality (measured by Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index) with no significant differences between groups. Actigraphy measures showed no significant changes overall, but a subsample with clinically significant sleep disturbances saw reductions in wake after sleep onset for both interventions.
population_specificity: 40 individuals with posttraumatic stress disorder (subsample of 24 with clinically significant sleep disturbances).
effective_dosage: Six sessions within 12 days (specific intensity protocols not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and preliminary effects of HIIT using FES cycling on thigh muscle volume and strength in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The study found high adherence, participant acceptability, and no serious adverse events, with notable improvements in quadriceps peak torque (13.9%-25.6%), hamstring strength (18.2%-23.3%), and leg volume (1.7%-18.2%).
population_specificity: Eight incomplete spinal cord injury patients (mean age 50 years; 6 women) with stable paraplegia (mean 6.75 years since injury).
effective_dosage: 85%-90% peak Watts; 4 × 4-min intervals, three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility, safety, and clinical effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in the early post-stroke stage.
results_summary: HIIT was found feasible and safe, with no serious adverse events reported. Significant improvements were observed in peak workload, balance, walking tests, and sit-to-stand performance.
population_specificity: Outpatients in Benin with a median age of 63.5 years, 15 days post-stroke.
effective_dosage: Three times/week, 20-30 minutes/session on a recumbent bike.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of different cardiac rehabilitation interventions, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), in improving outcomes for chronic heart failure patients.
results_summary: Center-based cardiac rehabilitation with HIIT was the most effective in enhancing left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF). Combined CR with aerobic and resistance training improved quality of life, exercise capacity, and reduced rehospitalization rates.
population_specificity: Chronic heart failure (CHF) patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of physical exercise, including high-intensity interval training, on cancer patients undergoing medical oncologic treatment, comparing outcomes between well-nourished and malnourished patients.
results_summary: The study found that physical exercise, including high-intensity interval training, improved physical function, quality of life, and lean body mass in both well-nourished and malnourished cancer patients, with varying degrees of benefit across outcomes. Compliance with exercise was reported in about 70% of studies, but the optimal regimen and exercise setting (e.g., home vs. supervised) remain unclear.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing medical oncologic treatment, categorized as well-nourished or malnourished.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) as part of lifestyle interventions for managing symptoms of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: The study found that HIIT, along with other lifestyle interventions like acupuncture and vitamin D3 supplementation, was effective in managing PCOS symptoms and improving overall health outcomes. These interventions complemented traditional medical therapies, highlighting the value of integrating lifestyle modifications into PCOS treatment plans.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the importance of exercise quantification in clinical settings, particularly focusing on High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) for preventive cardiology and overall well-being.
results_summary: The study highlights HIIT's central role in preventive cardiology, emphasizing tailored interventions, monitoring progress, and adherence to guidelines. It also notes the potential of advanced wearable technology and behavioral science to enhance long-term adherence and effectiveness.
population_specificity: Special populations including weekend warriors, "fat and fit" individuals, athletes, and those at risk of overtraining syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a 6-day HIT microcycle with multiple short work intervals and active recovery versus regular training on endurance performance in well-trained cyclists.
results_summary: The BLOCK group showed significantly larger improvements in mean power output during the last minute of maximal oxygen uptake testing compared to the regular training group.
population_specificity: Well-trained cyclists
effective_dosage: 5 × 8.75-min 30/15 s short intervals per session, five sessions over 6 days
study_duration: 6 days for BLOCK group, 12 days for REG group

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the adaptive responses of cardiorespiratory fitness, anaerobic power, and motor abilities in male volleyball players to two types of HIIT: interval running and interval jumping.
results_summary: Both HIIT interventions significantly improved maximum oxygen uptake (V̇O₂ max), with additional enhancements in aerobic fitness, cardiac function, anaerobic power, and motor abilities such as linear speed, agility, and jumping. The study did not report significant differences between the two HIIT methods.
population_specificity: Collegiate male volleyball players (n=24).
effective_dosage: 11 minutes of interval running or interval jumping (15 seconds of activity alternating with 15 seconds of passive recovery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of 3 and 6 weeks of intensity domain-based exercise training, including HIIT and SIT, on physiological responses in young healthy participants.
results_summary: The study found a significant time effect for the time constant, indicating physiological adaptations, but the abstract does not provide detailed outcome measures for HIIT specifically.
population_specificity: 84 young healthy participants (42 male, 42 female), age and sex-matched.
effective_dosage: Two three-week phases of three supervised sessions per week (work-matched protocols, except SIT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the utility of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and medium-intensity continuous training (MICT) in exercise-based cardiac rehabilitation (ExCR) and assess their clinical benefits.
results_summary: HIIT appears to offer better outcomes in recovering cardiovascular fitness compared to MICT, though MICT is more suited for severely debilitated patients requiring higher safety. The study highlights the need for individualized ExCR programs based on patient profiles.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with cardiac diseases, including those with severe functional degradation or comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of bicycle and treadmill high-intensity interval exercise training on knee health and articular cartilage volume in obese patients to identify healthier weight-loss exercise methods.
results_summary: Both groups showed reduced BMI and increased knee pain and local skin temperature, but the treadmill group experienced significant cartilage volume reduction, while the bicycle group did not. The differences between groups were statistically significant.
population_specificity: 60 patients with simple obesity.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes per session, five times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, perceived efficacy, and participation perspectives of a stair climbing-based exercise snack intervention compared to moderate-intensity continuous training in inactive young adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training, only stating the study's aim and population.
population_specificity: Healthy, young, inactive adults (age: 21.6 ± 2.3 years, BMI: 22.5 ± 3.6 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the variability in health responses to supervised high-intensity interval training (HIIT) among individuals with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study examined interindividual heterogeneity in responses to HIIT in adults with overweight/obesity and MetS, but specific outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: 264 adults with overweight/obesity and metabolic syndrome (mean age 56.3 ± 7.3 years, BMI 32.3 ± 4.7 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of carbohydrate timing and type on body composition and physical fitness in individuals undergoing High-Intensity Interval Training combined with resistance exercise.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in body composition (reduced body fat percentage and fat mass, increased fat-free mass) and physical fitness, regardless of carbohydrate timing or type. The results suggest that a balanced dietary plan with sufficient nutrient intake promotes these benefits independently of carbohydrate manipulation.
population_specificity: 42 healthy, trained male volunteers
effective_dosage: Not specified (carbohydrate intake was distributed differently among groups but exact amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the efficacy of aerobic exercise interventions, including High-Intensity Interval Training, in alleviating anxiety symptoms in individuals with Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD).
results_summary: The review found that aerobic exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training, demonstrated efficacy in reducing anxiety symptoms and improving overall well-being across diverse populations. However, limitations in study methodologies and heterogeneity across interventions warrant cautious interpretation of the results.
population_specificity: Diverse populations, including primary care patients, individuals with coronary heart disease, and older adults with cancer undergoing chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate differences between DXA-derived lean soft tissue (DXALST) and FFAT-corrected LST (FFATLST) across varied populations and interventions, including HIIT, to understand the application of the correction formula on LST outcomes.
results_summary: Significant differences between ΔDXALST and ΔFFATLST were observed in specific interventions (BARPRO and HIRTPRO), suggesting the FFAT correction may be particularly relevant in cases of significant weight loss or body recomposition. The study did not focus on HIIT's standalone efficacy but included it in combined interventions.
population_specificity: 226 subjects across five prior studies, including combined nutrition and exercise interventions (HIIT/HIRT) and post-bariatric surgery patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the intensity, enjoyment, and perceived exertion of a play-based HIIT program for children and adolescents with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that exercise intensity and perceived exertion varied by activity type, with ball games resulting in less high-intensity time and lower perceived exertion compared to strength- and running-based activities. Boys spent more time in moderate-intensity exercise and rated running-based activities as more enjoyable than girls.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with obesity (83 participants, 42.2% girls, 57.8% boys, ages 12.0±1.6 years).
effective_dosage: Three weekly sessions of a 4x4-minute play-based HIIT program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of different exercise methods, including High-Intensity Interval Training, on functional recovery after spinal cord injury from the perspective of exerkines mechanism.
results_summary: The study suggests that exercise training, including High-Intensity Interval Training, enhances skeletal muscle function, induces neuroprotection and regeneration, and improves motor function and daily living abilities in SCI patients, though the exact mechanisms remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients with spinal cord injury (SCI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in reducing chronic inflammation by analyzing its impact on specific inflammatory biomarkers in individuals with overweight and obesity.
results_summary: HIIT was identified as the most effective exercise modality for improving IL-6, TNF-α, and IL-10 levels, outperforming other exercise types like resistance training and aerobic exercise in these specific biomarkers. The study also noted a dose-response relationship between exercise intensity/duration and intervention effectiveness.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight and obesity (IOO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) with other exercise modalities on vascular endothelial function in middle-aged and older adults.
results_summary: HIIT was the second most effective exercise modality in improving flow-mediated dilation (FMD), with a SUCRA score of 62.5%, following aerobic exercise (68.9%).
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the most commonly used cardiac rehabilitation strategies, particularly High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), and their health benefits for patients with ventricular assist devices.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT was the most commonly used strategy, with intensities close to 90% of peak VO2, and was safe and beneficial for improving cardiorespiratory fitness and exercise tolerance in the short term.
population_specificity: Patients with ventricular assist devices and advanced heart failure.
effective_dosage: Intensities close to 90% of peak VO2 (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) in reducing body fat percentage for individuals with Normal Weight Obesity (NWO) and Overweight Obesity (OWO).
results_summary: HIIT showed the largest effect on reducing percentage body fat (MD: -6.8%, SE: 0.06) among the interventions studied, though the study noted a high risk of bias. It also led to greater increases in fat-free mass compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Individuals with BMI <30 kg/m² (NWO and OWO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different high-intensity interval training (HIIT) protocols and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on lipolytic hormone release and fat loss in obese young women.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study investigated the impact of HIIT and MICT on fat loss and hormone release in obese women.
population_specificity: 39 young women categorized as obese (body fat percentage ≥30%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) with moderate-to-vigorous physical activity for body weight regulation and overall health benefits.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT is not superior to moderate-to-vigorous physical activity for body weight regulation. Light-intensity physical activity may also be effective if it achieves sufficient energy expenditure, and multimodal physical activity is recommended for holistic health benefits beyond weight management.
population_specificity: General population, with considerations for sex, gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, age, and developmental level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a high-intensity interval training (HIIT) aerobic exercise program on neuropathic pain and quality of life in individuals with chronic paraplegia.
results_summary: The study will assess changes in neuropathic pain, its interference with daily activities, mood, sleep, quality of life, and aerobic capacity after 3 and 6 weeks of intervention, but results are not yet reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic paraplegia (neurological level of injury T2-L2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different exercise interventions, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on cancer pain in adults.
results_summary: The study found that comprehensive exercise programs (CEP) were most effective for relieving pain intensity, while mind-body exercise was best for reducing pain interference. HIIT was included among the exercise types analyzed, but its specific efficacy relative to other interventions was not highlighted in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer pain (3,537 patients across 41 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify research hotspots and frontier issues in exercise intervention for Type 2 Diabetes (T2D), with a focus on the potential benefits of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) due to its time efficiency.
results_summary: The study highlighted HIIT as gaining widespread attention for achieving similar exercise effects in a shorter duration compared to traditional aerobic and resistance training. Emerging areas of interest include circadian rhythm regulation and its impact on exercise outcomes for diabetic individuals.
population_specificity: Individuals with Type 2 Diabetes (T2D).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of exercise, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on irisin production and its potential therapeutic benefits for brain-related pathological conditions.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT, along with other forms of exercise, increases irisin levels, which may enhance insulin receptor phosphorylation and improve insulin-dependent pathways, potentially aiding in combating insulin resistance, inflammation, and cognitive decline. Irisin shows promise for therapeutic targeting in conditions like Alzheimer's disease, Parkinson's disease, epilepsy, type 2 diabetes, and obesity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of exercise effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on cardiopulmonary function in male tobacco-dependent college students.
results_summary: HIIT and MICT both improved cardiopulmonary function, but HIIT was superior to MICT in enhancing HRmax, HRR, FVC, FEV1, FEV1/FVC, and PEF. Tobacco dependence negatively correlated with several cardiopulmonary indicators.
population_specificity: Male tobacco-dependent college students (45 participants in the TB group, with subgroups for HIIT, MICT, and non-exercise).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effect of exercise timing (morning, afternoon, or evening) on glycemic control and metabolic health parameters in individuals with T2DM and those at risk during a 12-week HIIT intervention.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be a proposed or ongoing trial.
population_specificity: Individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and age-matched older adults with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: Three 2-week blocks of supervised post-prandial HIIT, with 2-week washout periods between blocks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize evidence on the efficacy of interval training compared to moderate-intensity continuous training and nonexercise control in reducing body adiposity in healthy adults.
results_summary: Interval training showed significantly greater reductions in total body fat percent compared to both moderate-intensity continuous training and nonexercise control, with benefits more prominent in individuals with overweight/obesity, longer interventions (≥12 weeks), cycling protocols, and low-volume HIIT.
population_specificity: Apparently healthy adults, with subgroup analyses focusing on individuals with overweight/obesity.
effective_dosage: Low-volume HIIT (<15 min of high-intensity exercise per session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 12-week HIIT program on cardiometabolic biomarkers in patients with prostate cancer on active surveillance.
results_summary: The HIIT program significantly improved total cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, insulin, IGF-1, and IGFBP-3 levels compared to usual care, but no significant changes were observed in fasting glucose, HbA1c, other lipid markers, IGFBP-1, adiponectin, or leptin.
population_specificity: Men with prostate cancer on active surveillance (mean age 63.4 ± 7.1 years, 40% obese).
effective_dosage: Supervised aerobic HIIT at 85-95% VO2max (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a 6-month home-based HIIT intervention in improving cardiorespiratory fitness in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that the HIIT group showed significant improvements in peak oxygen consumption (V̇O₂) and lactate threshold (LT) compared to the control group, with clinically meaningful outcomes. The LT improvement was more pronounced than V̇O₂ changes.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 60-84 years (54% females).
effective_dosage: Thrice-weekly home-based HIIT (once-weekly circuit training and twice-weekly interval training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on serum myonectin, lipid metabolism, and body composition in adults with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: HIIT was not superior to MICT in improving serum myonectin, lipid profile, or body composition measures, though HIIT alone significantly increased myonectin compared to baseline. Both interventions reduced appendicular fat mass and increased lean mass with large effect sizes, but neither affected intramuscular lipids or free fatty acids.
population_specificity: Adults of both sexes with metabolic syndrome (mean age 50.8±6.0 years, BMI 30.6±4.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: HIIT: six 1-minute intervals at 90% VO2peak (total 22 min), 3 times/week. MICT: 60% VO2peak for 36 min, 3 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) and Moderate-Intensity Continuous Training (MICT) on weight, body composition, blood lipid indicators, and metabolic status in obese college students.
results_summary: HIIT showed a more favorable declining trend than MICT in body fat percentage and biochemical markers, with greater reductions in male and female HIIT groups. Significant differences were observed between HIIT and MICT groups for body fat percentage and certain biochemical indicators.
population_specificity: 40 obese college students (20 males, 20 females) aged 18-25.
effective_dosage: HIIT: 28 min per session (4 min at 85-90% max heart rate, 3 min at 50-60% max heart rate, repeated 4 times), 3 sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether high-intensity interval training (HIIT) could optimize the benefits of exercise training in pulmonary rehabilitation for idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) patients.
results_summary: The study found emerging evidence that HIIT may enhance the benefits of exercise training in IPF patients, improving exercise tolerance, symptoms, and quality of life, though long-term functional capacity benefits require further research.
population_specificity: People with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the long-term (5-year) effects of two High-Intensity Interval Training programs (RT-HIIT and AT-HIIT) on health outcomes, including cancer-related fatigue and physical function, in breast cancer patients undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant long-term differences in cancer-related fatigue between the intervention groups and usual care, though RT-HIIT reduced pain sensitivity and AT-HIIT showed clinically meaningful (but non-significant) improvements in cognitive fatigue and cardiorespiratory fitness. Short-term benefits in fatigue reduction and physical function were noted, but effects diminished over time.
population_specificity: 240 patients with breast cancer undergoing adjuvant chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of RT-HIIT or AT-HIIT (specific frequency/intensity not detailed in abstract).
study_duration: 16 weeks of intervention, with a 5-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intermittent fasting combined with high-intensity interval training (HIIT) could remodel the gut microbiota composition in women with obesity.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT, combined or not with intermittent fasting, influenced gut microbiota composition in obese women, suggesting potential benefits for obesity treatment. However, specific outcomes or statistical significance were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Thirty-six women with obesity, aged 18–40 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility, safety, and effectiveness of a multimodal prehabilitation program, including High-Intensity Interval Training, for improving physical fitness in patients with cirrhosis awaiting liver transplantation.
results_summary: The study assessed feasibility, adherence, and acceptability of the intervention, including High-Intensity Interval Training, but did not report specific efficacy outcomes in the abstract. Changes in exercise capacity, nutritional status, and quality of life were evaluated, with post-transplantation outcomes recorded.
population_specificity: Adult patients with cirrhosis active on the liver transplantation waiting list at McGill University Health Centre.
effective_dosage: Aerobic training individualized based on cardiopulmonary exercise testing, including High-Intensity Interval Training on a cycle ergometer (three sessions per week for 4 weeks, then one session every other week for 20 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of different exercise modalities, including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on HbA1c levels in patients with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT had the highest ranked effect in reducing HbA1c levels (MD = -0.78%), followed by combined aerobic and resistance exercise, yoga, and continuous aerobic exercise. A significant improvement in HbA1c levels was observed when the total exercise dose reached 840 metabolic equivalent of tasks-min/week.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (5,535 participants across 85 randomized controlled trials).
effective_dosage: Total exercise dose of 840 metabolic equivalent of tasks-min/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 10-week HIIT intervention, combined with moderate alcohol consumption, on cognitive performance in healthy young adults.
results_summary: All groups showed improvements in neuropsychological measures, but these could not be attributed to HIIT alone. No significant cognitive impairments were noted due to moderate alcohol intake, and exercise-induced fitness improvements were associated with cognitive enhancements.
population_specificity: 75 healthy adults aged 18-40 (46% female).
effective_dosage: HIIT program (2 days/week); alcohol beverages (5.4% alcohol content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 10-month energy restriction and exercise intervention on liver histology, anthropometrics, plasma biochemistries, and insulin sensitivity in individuals with metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced body weight, fat mass, and liver injury while improving cardiorespiratory fitness and peripheral insulin sensitivity, leading to clinically meaningful improvements in liver health. The results suggest that exercise and energy restriction may redistribute excess nutrients to skeletal muscle, reducing hepatic nutrient toxicity.
population_specificity: Individuals with biopsy-proven metabolic dysfunction-associated steatohepatitis (MASH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of HIIT on cardiorespiratory fitness and glycemic parameters in patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM) and determine the most effective HIIT protocol for these outcomes.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved cardiorespiratory fitness and 24-h mean glucose control in T1DM patients but did not significantly affect fasting glucose or HbA1C levels. Compared to a control group, HIIT showed favorable effects on HbA1C, but no specific HIIT protocol characteristics moderated the outcomes.
population_specificity: Adult patients with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM), free of complications and other diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional HIIT and high-intensity circuit training (HICT) on lipid profiles and inflammatory cytokine levels in sedentary young women.
results_summary: The study investigated the impact of HIIT and HICT but did not report specific results in the abstract. The abstract mentions the assignment of participants to different groups but lacks outcome details.
population_specificity: Sedentary young women (n=42)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of acute HIIT combined with tDCS on inhibitory control and working memory in healthy young adults.
results_summary: Acute HIIT combined with tDCS improved inhibitory control (measured by Stroop task response times) but did not show cumulative benefits on inhibitory control or working memory compared to other conditions. No significant differences were found in composite scores of the Stroop task or 2-back task performance.
population_specificity: 25 healthy college students (20.5 ± 1.3 years; 11 females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different HIIT protocols versus MICT on cardiorespiratory parameters in patients with heart failure subtypes.
results_summary: HIIT was generally more effective than MICT at improving peak oxygen consumption (Vo₂), with long-interval and high-volume HIIT protocols showing greater benefits for cardiopulmonary fitness in HFrEF patients.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF), including different HF subtypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the acute effects of HIIT on cortical excitability, M1-related cognitive functions, and cognition-related myokines (BDNF and CTSB) in sedentary young adults.
results_summary: HIIT improved mental rotation and working memory, increased serum levels of BDNF and CTSB, but did not alter cortical excitability. The findings suggest that a single HIIT session positively impacts cognitive functions and myokine levels.
population_specificity: Sedentary young adults (mean age: 22.78 years ± 2.87; 14 female).
effective_dosage: 23 minutes of HIIT in a single session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical fitness adaptations between small-sided games (SSG) and running-based HIIT, while also examining sex differences and intra-individual variations in adaptations.
results_summary: The study found significant interactions between time, groups, and sex in the 10-meter sprint test, suggesting differential effects of HIIT and SSG based on sex and training type.
population_specificity: Developmental/trained soccer players (25 women and 27 men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and increased steps on anthropometric, body mass, and body composition changes in sedentary, obese women over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The HIIT group showed statistically significant improvements in biceps, hips, and thigh measurements, along with body mass and body composition changes, suggesting health benefits. The study supports integrating physical activity interventions in the workplace to reduce obesity-related risks.
population_specificity: Sedentary, obese women with a BMI of 32.98 ± 3.21 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of jumping interval training (JIT) and running high-intensity interval training (HIIT) on aerobic, anaerobic, and jumping performance in youth female aerobic gymnasts.
results_summary: Both JIT and HIIT significantly improved aerobic and anaerobic performance compared to the control group, with JIT showing additional benefits in vertical jumping performance. The control group showed significantly lower scores in all tests post-intervention compared to the experimental groups.
population_specificity: 73 youth female aerobic gymnasts (16.2 ± 1.3 years old).
effective_dosage: Two additional training sessions per week alongside regular training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of small-sided games (SSG) and short interval running-based HIIT in improving aerobic capacity, change-of-direction abilities, and jumping performance in youth female soccer players.
results_summary: The study found significant interactions in countermovement jump (CMJ) performance, suggesting HIIT may improve jumping ability, but the abstract does not provide full details on aerobic capacity or change-of-direction outcomes.
population_specificity: 48 female youth soccer players under age 19 competing at the regional level.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and initial efficacy of a 12-week HIIT program using a recumbent stepper in persons with MS who have walking disability.
results_summary: The study found high adherence (97%) and participant satisfaction (4.7/5), with significant improvements in cognitive processing speed, physical activity, and walking, but no significant changes in fitness, arm function, or walking tests. Large effect sizes were noted for peak power output and fatigue severity despite non-significant statistical changes.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (MS) who have walking disability (Patient Determined Disability Steps scale score 3.0-7.0).
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week HIIT program using a recumbent stepper).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of omega-3 supplementation on delayed onset muscle soreness (DOMS), muscle damage, and acute inflammatory markers induced by cycling HIIT in untrained males with overweight or obesity.
results_summary: The study used a randomized, double-blinded design to compare omega-3 supplementation (4 g fish oil) with a placebo over 4 weeks, assessing its impact on DOMS and related markers after HIIT. Results regarding the effectiveness of omega-3 were not fully detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Untrained males with overweight or obesity and a sedentary lifestyle.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increasing exercise dose or changing exercise mode (including high-intensity interval training) could improve blood pressure reduction in postmenopausal women who did not respond to traditional aerobic exercise.
results_summary: High-intensity interval training (HIIT) was 100% effective in reducing systolic blood pressure among non-responders, outperforming continuous aerobic training at higher intensities or frequencies. Traditional aerobic exercise alone was insufficient for most participants, but modifying exercise type or dose improved outcomes.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with essential hypertension (n=65, with 34 non-responders to initial aerobic training).
effective_dosage: HIIT protocol details not specified; continuous aerobic training was performed 3-4 times/week.
study_duration: Initial 12-week aerobic training, followed by an additional 12-week intervention for non-responders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of aerobic exercise training (AET), including High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on cardiorespiratory fitness, cardiovascular morbidity, and cancer therapy-related cardiac dysfunction (CTRCD) in cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that AET, including HIIT, is safe and effective in improving cardiorespiratory fitness and reducing cardiovascular morbidity and heart failure hospitalization in cancer patients. However, the long-term effects on CTRCD and the optimal exercise regimen remain unclear.
population_specificity: Cancer patients at risk of cancer therapy-related cardiac dysfunction (CTRCD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of high-intensity interval training combined with resistance training (2 days per week) versus a 5:2 diet and routine lifestyle education on glycemic control and cardiometabolic health in adults with overweight/obesity and type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The exercise intervention (high-intensity interval training and resistance training) did not significantly improve glycemic control compared to the control group but was superior in maintaining lean body mass and improved adiposity and hepatic steatosis.
population_specificity: Adults with overweight/obesity and type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 2 days per week of high-intensity interval training and resistance training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether muscle contraction during high-intensity interval training (HIIT) alters the release of cytokines (adiponectin, leptin, IL6) and affects bone remodeling in overweight women.
results_summary: The study found that acute HIIT sessions increased IL6 and P1NP levels, suggesting enhanced bone formation, while 16 weeks of HIIT maintained bone mineral density (BMD) in the exercise group compared to a decrease in the control group. Resting adiponectin levels increased post-intervention but were not linked to bone biomarkers or BMD.
population_specificity: Overweight, premenopausal women (n=22).
effective_dosage: 40-minute HIIT sessions at 80-90% of heart rate reserve, 3 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on depressive symptoms, including its impact across different populations, intervention durations, and control groups.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that HIIT had a small but significant effect on reducing depressive symptoms compared to control groups, with moderate improvements observed when compared to non-active controls. The study supports HIIT as a beneficial intervention for alleviating depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: 1,607 participants across 34 randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of low-volume combined aerobic and resistance high-intensity interval training (C-HIIT) versus combined moderate-intensity continuous training (C-MICT) on vascular health in adults with type 2 diabetes (T2D) over short-term supervised and long-term self-directed training periods.
results_summary: Short-term supervised C-HIIT significantly improved flow-mediated dilation (FMD) compared to control, while C-MICT showed a similar but non-significant trend. Long-term, both C-HIIT and C-MICT improved hemodynamic indices, but C-MICT was superior to C-HIIT in reducing carotid-femoral pulse wave velocity (cfPWV) at 12 months.
population_specificity: Low-active adults with type 2 diabetes (T2D).
study_duration: 8 weeks of supervised training followed by 10 months of self-directed training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of exercise, particularly High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT), on flow-mediated dilation (FMD) in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and identify optimal exercise parameters.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that exercise significantly improved FMD in T2DM patients, with HIIT recommended more than 3 times per week for less than 60 minutes per session, targeting 180 minutes weekly.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: More than 3 times per week, less than 60 minutes per session, targeting 180 minutes weekly.

study_goal: To assess the impact of interval training programs, including high-intensity interval training, on hemodynamic variables (blood pressure and heart rate) in coronary artery bypass graft surgery patients.
results_summary: Interval training showed mild improvement in decreasing systolic blood pressure (small effect size of -0.226) and had small effects on diastolic blood pressure (effect size 0.136) and heart rate (effect size 0.155). The effects were modest and not statistically significant in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and tolerability of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIT) in hospitalized postoperative patients after major surgery.
results_summary: The study found that HIT was safe, with no protocol deviations, cohort crossover, or safety events reported. HIT resulted in higher perceived exertion, shorter exercise completion time, and a trend toward higher gait speed compared to continuous ambulation.
population_specificity: Hospitalized postoperative patients (median age ~64, predominantly White, with cancer diagnoses, and undergoing gastrointestinal surgery).
effective_dosage: Not specified (exercise parameters: HIT vs. low-intensity continuous ambulation over 40m).
study_duration: Initial inpatient stay after major surgery (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare stair-climbing-based exercise snacks (ES) to moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) for improving cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and to explore if ES could enhance maximal fat oxidation rate (MFO) in inactive adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study focused on comparing ES and MICT for CRF improvement and MFO enhancement in inactive adults.
population_specificity: Healthy, young, inactive adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 16-week high-intensity interval training (HIIT) and moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) on the composition of the oral microbiota in older adults.
results_summary: HIIT produced significant differences in microbial richness and a trend toward decreased diversity indices, while MICT showed an upward trend in diversity indices and altered bacterial phyla levels. Both exercise types led to significant changes in pathogenic species abundance.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60-74 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a 7-day high-intensity interval training shock microcycle (HIIT-SM) with or without additional low-intensity training (LIT) on aerobic fitness and endurance performance compared to a control group.
results_summary: The study found that HIIT-SM with or without additional LIT had negligible effects on maximal oxygen uptake (V̇O2max) but improved velocity at lactate threshold and 5-km time trial performance in endurance-trained athletes. No superiority was observed between the intervention groups, suggesting additional LIT during HIIT-SM is not beneficial.
population_specificity: Thirty-three endurance-trained athletes (7 women, 26 men, mean age 30.2 ± 6.9 years, V̇O2max 59.8 ± 4.9 mL·min⁻¹·kg⁻¹).
effective_dosage: HSM group: 10 running-based HIIT sessions (5 × 4 min at 90%-95% maximal heart rate) over 7 days; HSM + LIT group: same HIIT sessions plus 30 min of LIT after each HIIT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess postexertional symptoms and physiologic mechanisms in patients with post-COVID condition (PCC) after high-intensity interval training (HIIT) compared to controls.
results_summary: Patients with PCC reported greater exacerbation of muscle pain after HIIT compared to controls, but there was no significant difference in fatigue worsening between groups. PCC patients showed lower aerobic capacity and muscle strength but generally tolerated exercise without severe adverse effects.
population_specificity: Nonhospitalized patients with post-COVID condition (PCC) and persistent symptoms (≥3 months), along with age- and sex-matched healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of HIIT on depressive and anxiety symptoms in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant effect of HIIT on reducing anxiety or depressive symptoms in healthy individuals, with evidence of very low certainty.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals (81% female)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic effects of moderate-intensity constant training (MICT) versus high-intensity interval training (HIIT) in candidates preparing for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Both MICT and HIIT improved aerobic capacity, but only MICT maintained these improvements at follow-up. HIIT increased adiponectin post-training and GDF15 at follow-up, while MICT reduced fat mass, increased muscle mass, and improved insulin response.
population_specificity: 25 candidates (22 women) aged 18-60 years preparing for sleeve gastrectomy.
effective_dosage: 10 sessions (2-3 times/week, 30 minutes per session) over 4 weeks.
study_duration: 4 weeks before surgery, with follow-up 1 month post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of High-Intensity Interval Training (HIIT) on oxygen consumption, quality of life, and mortality in adults with coronary heart disease.
results_summary: HIIT significantly improved peak oxygen consumption (MD 4.5 mL/kg/min) and quality of life (SMD 0.9), though it did not show a statistically significant reduction in mortality compared to other exercise interventions.
population_specificity: Adults with coronary heart disease.
